Award.AbstractNarration:

Yang

The over-arching objective of the proposed research and educational plan is further utilization of the expertise that the PI has in the area of optical imaging in order to develop better modalities of imaging using contrast agents with OCT, develop a miniaturized, forward looking OCT probe, seek wider application for OCT among biological and biomedical fields and develop a miniature optical microscope that uses microfluidics to move imaged object over an imaging platform. The educational objectives have a focus on development of the student's mind as a whole, by inclusion of intuitive understanding as well as encouragement towards other endeavors such as artistic expression.

Project Outcomes Report

 

Project Title: CAREER: Proposal for Developing Enhanced Optical Coherence Tomography Systems And Optofluidic Systems for Biomedical Applications.


PI: Changhuei Yang
Awardee: California Institute of Technology
Award Number: 0547657
Award Expires:01/31/2012
Program Officer Name: Leon Esterowitz
Program Officer Email Address: lesterow@nsf.gov

This award allowed us to work on chip scale microscope systems, specifically the optofluidic microscope (OFM), that are aimed at addressing the cost and throughput issues associated with conventional microscopy. The OFM method can enable the creation of low cost, compact and high throughput microscope systems. The working principle is similar to the way we see floaters in our eyes. The OFM flows target samples over a line of apertures that are specially patterned onto a low cost CMOS sensor chip. Each aperture in effect acquires a line scan of the sample. By appropriately compositing all the acquired line scans, we can then generate a high-resolution microscopy image of the samples. The application range of this invention is wide: it can change the way biologists think about and use microscope, it can enable clinical point-of-care blood and urine analysis, and it can improve healthcare by streamlining petri dish procedures.

            In addition, this award supported our work on Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT). OCT works on a principle that is to sonar, except here, light takes the place of sound. This allows us to image with a much finer resolution and potentially detect biochemical signatures from the scanned tissues. Our OCT probe technology can benefit surgeons in the surgical environment by providing an easy-to-control and robust imaging technique.
